text: Cask @ Wilkes Head,Leek,Staffs amber equity a white head with a citrus,malty and lemon taste which leaves not unpleasant citrus,malty aftertaste not bad.

Light grain malts, straw, subtle floral hops. Clear gold, small, frothy, white head. Light bitter. Bitterness intensifies, grain malts, floral hops, average duration, thin texture, quite light bodied. Boring Golden Ale, nothing special really. Cask at GBBF16, Olympia.
Cask at GBBF 2016, Olympia, London. A straw coloured pour with a medium white head on top. Hoppy, malty, citrus aroma. Tastes hoppy, malty, citrus, slight caramel. Decent and drinkable.

Cask at GBBF 2016 - Day 5. Pours clear gold with a frothy, white head. The nape has zesty and pithy citrus, lemon, dry pale bread. Light sweet flavorbwith flinty minerality, some grass, lemon peel. Light bodied with fine carboantion; good condition. Lightly grassy on the finish, with more citrus pith, minerals, hay. Nice golde.

Cask in the White Swan, Chesterfield. Golden with a foamy off white head. Not much aroma. The taste is citrus with toasty malts. Pleasantly bitter. Nice, but I was expecting a little more given its high rating.

Cask. Gravity dispense. Barrow Hill jamboree. Clear straw colour. White head. Nose has peach melba. Biscuit. Grain. Straw. Taste is soft sweet and light, well balanced bitter. Fruity, citric bitter finish. Nice one.

Tried at Rail Ale Beer Festival on 20th May 2016. Pours clear golden with a thin white head. Malt and citrus aromas. Tastes floral, citrus, plenty of hop notes and a little grass. Really decent gold. Liked it.

Cask at the Rail Ale Festival Chesterfield, 2016. Poured a crystal clear straw colour with a bubbly white head. The aroma is grassy citrus hop. The flavour is moderate bitter with a fruity dry spicy hop bitter palate. Light bodied with soft carbonation.

Cask at Rail Ale 16, 20/05/16.
Pale golden blonde with a well appointed off White cap.
Nose is juicy citric flesh, tangerine, light floral hop exhaust, orange pith.
Taste comprises citric sherbets, light peach notes, tangerines, soft bread dough.
Medium bodied, soft carbonation, semi drying close with a juicy hop flicker.
Solid golde ... worthy of its top 50 status.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Cask at Chesterfield Rail Ale Jolly with RB crew; straw yellow pour with a thin white head, aroma has sweet malts and a load of citrus action, taste has tangerine, grapefruit, biscuit, a little dankness, decent hote.
Clear golden colour, thin white head, lovely hoppy aroma and refreshing citrus/hop flavours, cracking beer!

Cask at The Wilkes Head, Leek. A golden colour with a thin white head. Aroma of grapefruit, apple, pear and big floral hops. Taste of apple, pear, grapefruit, lemon peel, grassy, floral hops and resin. Medium bodied and an oily texture. A long floral hop bitterness in the finish. A really good golden ale, full of floral and citrus hops.

Cask conditioned at The Wilkes Head, Leek, Staffs. Gold with white head. A big and fruity golden ale, tangy grapefruit juice, pithy, drying. There is a lasting hoppiness, light greengage hints. Really very decent.

Hand pulled at King William IV, Nottingham. Gold, with fabulous lacing. Smells OK. Flavour is really good. Big, booming UK style hoppiness: some floral, some medicine, some cat piss. A great Golden ale.

On cask at the 2012 NWAF, Manchester. Pours a golden colour with a thick white head. The aroma is quite floral with grass, caramel and green tea notes. Just a little sweet with similar floral flavours of grass, green tea and caramel. Nice lingering bitterness with moderate carbonation and an oily mouth-feel. Tasty.

Cask conditioned	Handpump	Brunswick	Derby.  A light golden beer with a white head and lacing.  Good strong citrussy hops in the aroma.  Sharp bitterness in the mouth.  A little acidity and becomes a bit harsh but otherwise OK.

Cask at NWAF, 2011. Golden/yellow pour with a white head. Citrus aromas, quite floral with a hint of caramel. Citrus flavours with pear, peach and lots of lovely hops. Sharp hop tang. Good hoppy, fruity finish. Tasty brew.

Cask at Marble Arch Inn, Manchester. A hazy light golden beer with a thin orangey head. The aroma is very perfumy - from the hops. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt, flowers, and hops, leading to a dry, bitter, fruity, and hoppy finish.
On cask at Kingston beer festival: Disinfectant lemon flavours throughout though it remains surprisingly pleasant.

Cask, handpump at The Flowerpot ,Derby 30-01-10 in company of Loz, Simon (Haddonsman) my dad and Pauline    Pours clear as a bell golden with a slim white head. Touch of fruitiness on the nose, lightly bitter on the nose but then there is a nice tingle from the hops and a light burn on the tongue, nice furry bitterness. Really lovely stuff, good citrus flavours coming through, lemon peel, clingy, stringy bitterness continuing, great beer but alongside Marble Dobber its in some very special company.  A7 A5 F7 P4 Ov14   43.7

Cask - The Bull, Horton Kirby. Poured a clear, bright golden colour with a fine, short white head. Dry hoppy, somewhat lagery nose with grapefruit, floral & grassy notes. Packed with fresh hops: grapefruit, lemon, lemon sherbet, grass, pine & pepper. Crisp, refreshing, bit like a good pils in terms of mouthfeel, a touch of sting with a medium body & finish.

Cask Stillage at Edgeley Park, Stockport 29/05/2009
Fruit and hop aromas. Clear golden coloured hoppy and fruity grapefruit flavour. A little creamy on the palate with a crisp slightly bitter and dry malt finish.
Yellow with a small white head. Hoppy aroma with perfumed orange peel. Dry and hoppy flavour with orange notes. Very bitter

Cask @ GBBF 2008. Pours a pale yellow color with a longlasting white head. Has a fruity hoppy bitter grapefruit aroma. Fruity malty hoppy bitter grapefruit flavor. Has a fruity malty hoppy grapefruit finish.

Cask, Peterborough Fest 08.  Golden with a white head.  Aromas are biscuit malts with peppery, bitter hops.  Floral, fruity and crisp.  Flavours are green pine with sweet citrus.  Bitter with a very long aftertaste.

Cask at the SIBA bar at the GBBF 2008, hand pump. Golden colour, low head. Lovely aroma of tropical fruits and flowers. The flavour has tropical fruits and grapefruit throughout, convincingly hopped but not too bitter. The aftertaste is quite bitter though.

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ Golden colour, small white head. Aroma is sweet fruits and flowery hops along with mild notes of nectary sweetness. Flavour is a lot of grassy hops, some mild spices and wood. Long spicy and grassy finish.
Cask at GBBF 08. Bright gold and served in perfect condition. Awesome floral hop aroma, a great mouthfeel with citrus and hops dominant and a superb dry finish. Very close to the perfect summer ale.
Clear golden with tiny white head. Sweet fruity aroma with pine, citrus and hoppy notes. Sweet fruity flavor with hoppy, caramel and grapefruit notes. Ends solid bitter.

Cask, handpull, Smithfield Derby. As Half Man Half Biscuit almost sang, there is nothing better in life than writing on the sole of your slipper with a Biro on a Thursday night instead of going to the pub unless it’s the Smithfield and you have to choose between Thornbridge, Oakham and Whim. The answer’s obvious - have the Inferno and Kipling later and enjoy Flower Power first. As orange clears to rugged gold, hop oil escapes the oversize glass. Like an overstocked market stall, the sharp citrics and soft flowers occasionally struggle for attention but on the whole the beer works - and works hard at balance to be a winner. Great on its own, better as a palate-loosener for the other goodies often on at the Smithy.
Cask at the Smithfield, Derby. Gold with a dense white head; fruity aroma; thick and oily with a bitter orange flavour and a deeply bitter finish.
Cask at the King William IV, Nottingham. This pale beer has a fresh, floral aroma and a flavour which is very nicely balanced between sweet tropical fruit and citrus bitterness. Very enjoyable.

Cask (handpump) @ The National Winter Ales Festival 2008, Manchester, UK. Clear light to medium yellow orange color with a average, frothy fizzy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is light to moderate malty, toasted, moderate hoppy, flowers, perfume, grape, lemon. Flavor is moderate sweet and moderate to light heavy bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft to flat. (170108)
3rd one to rate this beer! Woo hoo! Not my preferred style of beer, it was ok though. A little soapy for me, very drinkable though.

UPDATED: AUG 8, 2008 A Mes rate: Cask at The Crown.Excellent clean blonde colour with the creamy white head and lace showing its excellent condition. Superb floral and aromatic hops. Almost soapy but it stops just short. Amazing bitter and dry grassy finish. Damn tasty!

UPDATED: AUG 15, 2008 Cask gravity at Nottingham BF 2007.  Gold clear beer.  Glorious grapefruit aroma.  Good carbonation.  Extraordinary hop.  Very intense lychees.  Very drinkable.  Good balance yet still intense hop.  Sherbert.  Well done, though. 4.1/5
Re-rate Cask from GBBF 08.  A really hoppy strong gold ale.  Soft in mouth.  Great peppery English EKG style hops.  Wow.  The hops, the mouth feel, the lemon curd fruit.  Great stunning bitterness.
